text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: And uh the study that we have, which we have open right now is called the Transformer Trial. It’s an acronym. You don’t need to remember that. We’ll give you information about that – to read it. Patient: I appreciate that, thanks. Doctor: It’s called the Transformer Trial because it was funded by a grant that was called the Transformative Impact Grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And so we applied for a grant at the Department of Defense, actually, DOD. And they have a program whereby they support prostate cancer studies. Patient: DOD? Doctor: Yeah, the DOD. Patient: Wow. Doctor: I know; a lot of people are surprised. And this was a grant where the DOD wanted to fund a project that would a small benefit or have a transformative benefit. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In other words a pretty huge benefit. And they were also looking for things that were paradigm shifts. In other words that runs against the grain. And so one of my colleagues from H___ applied for this grant. His name is Dr. ___. He was the mastermind behind this approach. Patient: Uh huh.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
